review_title: Pay could be better and consistent
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: While working on a degree, it's nice to be compensated for it because you do make meaningful contributions to your field.
cons: The compensation varies from department to department. Usually, it is enough for a single person to survive, but you're going to have difficulty if you have dependents or other financial obligations. There is also no built-in structure for increasing the pay as the cost of living increases. Expectations vary wildly from research group to research group, even within a department. Some groups expect you to work on the precipice of burnout; others provide very little guidance.

pros: Benefits: Large college tuition reduction for employee, spouse and children, Earned retirement pension, 22 days vacation per year (if you are granted permission to use it), vacation rollover each year of 325 hours, accumulated sick time per pay period, accumulated vacation time per pay period
cons: Collaboration between College of Medicine and Banner Healthcare is terrible. Staff is expected to know all policies and procedures (which are different) for BOTH U of A and Banner. College of Medicine does not want people working from home, but Banner allows it. Causes much confusion and resentment. A lot of upper department leaders leave which leaves staff wondering where they stand in there jobs. You have to pay for parking at about $700 per year (payroll deduction) whether you are full or part time (no discount for part time). A lot of turnover across the U of A with not enough training or professional development for staff, who are basically the ones left to run the organization! The benefits kept me working here, but not much more than that. I would recommend working at the U of A, but not at the College of Medicine.

pros: There are no pros!!! Stress that causes your hair to fall out and develop high blood pressure is an indicator that the company is unorganized and mismanaged.
cons:
Is this a joke? Am I in the twilight zone?! UAGC expects miracles to be performed and for us to enroll and retain these people who have ZERO intention and ZERO business trying to attend an online university! 

They’re either TikTok grant chasers: “Yea, how do I get that grant? I need to pay my rent and car note.” 

Are coming out of prison: “I paid my dues to society, and I want to do better, but I have no computer skills, no stable living environment, and no computer.” 

Actively using substances: “……” 

Have zero computer skills: “What’s a URL?” 

Homeless: “I’m not sure where I’ll be living next week, but yea let’s get me enrolled!” 

Pipe dreamers: “I want the degree so badly, but (insert a million excuses).” 

Have fake high-school diplomas: “Click.” 

Don’t have computers: “Oh, I’m going to use that grant money to buy a computer.” 

And yet UAGC threatens enrollment advisors for not being able to enroll these people?! Are you serious?! 

How much is UAGC paying for these “quality” leads? $50 for 200 leads?! No, I’m sure it’s more like $97 for 345, right? Whatever they’re paying for these leads, it’s not enough. 

And leadership is well aware! But, rather than pay for quality leads or, I don’t know, implement resources that will assist their enrollment advisors, actually ENROLL quality students, such as a laptop program or a basic computer course (because, let’s face it, they’re already a Devry or UOP with all of their lawsuits, so they may as well go the full throttle); they instead choose to belittle enrollment advisors and use us as scapegoats!!! 

Stop gaslighting people who have good work ethics because you refuse to pay for quality leads!!! These leads are crap!!! And again, leadership is well aware!  What kills me is the fact that these managers wouldn’t even be able to convert and retain these people either, yet, they are consistently dangling termination in front of our faces. Lol. 

9/10 of the prospects are coming out of prison, have fake high school diplomas, no computers, and only talk to us because TikTok tells them they’ll get a grant that same day. How dare UAGC use your employees as scapegoats. And don’t get me started on the fact that enrollment advisors must also act as financial aid advisors in assisting these prospects with their financial aid documents, which you’ve guessed it takes an immense amount of time away from actual enrollment activities that we’re later held accountable for!

To make matters worse, leaders then have the AUDACITY to berate employees in front of other employees in stitch meetings—shame on you, UAGC. And in case anyone is confused, Ashford=Zovio=UAGC, do not let all of the names fool you- they are all the same. Zovio, was FIRED from UAGC, and UAGC is about to lose its WASC accreditation. And yet the gaslighting continues?! It’s not the enrollment advisors that are the problem; it’s the ineffective upper management.

May UAGC be sued next and never recover. May a class action lawsuit materialize where all of the good people of UAGC and it’s ineffective and shameful management, philosophy, and business practices wronged and stressed out be afforded a large settlement that helps them to attempt to forget the trauma UAGC caused them.

- Great education in my master's degree.

- Even for a low-cost city, barely enough to live on. Incredibly low pay.

review_title: Good work-life balance, bad opportunities for growth
job_title: Higher Education Administrator in Tucson, AZ
pros: Working in higher education as staff is great for work-life balance (as long as you draw your own lines). The University of Arizona is no different. I enjoyed most of my positions at the company and definitely loved the people I had the opportunity to work with.
cons: You will never get a raise or a promotion as staff at this institution. In the seven years I worked there, I applied for and was hired for increasing positions 5+ times, pretty much every time I asked for a (deserved) raise and was strung along. It feels like the mentality for University staff is much like that for teachers - administration expects that all staff have a spouse that makes the "real" money and you're doing work out of the goodness of your heart, so they don't feel they have to equitably pay you. You have to make your own promotions by applying for new positions, because they will not reward hard work monetarily.

pros: Most areas have a fairly relaxed atmosphere and give employees some autonomy and a little flexibility. Benefits in terms of paid time off for sick and vacation, insurance, tuition breaks and etc. are above average.
cons: A huge chunk of your paycheck is taken every pay period for ASRS. You have no choice about this. Some departments, including the one where I worked, are absolutely horrible about abusing employees in terms of overtime. In addition, every time someone left, management would either not replace them at all, or would "underfill" the position with someone with far less experience. This resulted in a crumbling infrastructure, putting tremendous pressure on remaining employees to pick up the slack. These poor souls were never compensated in any way for this extra workload, and instead were told they should be damn thankful they still had a job. For my specific profession, the salaries are FAR less than one would make in other settings. All in all, I would not recommend UA to any prospective employee, unless you are ready to be abused, and you, your spouse, or your kids need the reduced tuition rates.

job_title: Support Systems Analyst  in Tucson, AZ
pros: The health  benefits at the UofA are some of the best I have seen anywhere outside of the Military.
cons:
A lot has changed at  the UofA over the ten years I was there, it went from a first rate university that managed to keep the feel of smaller institutions. Now it is becoming a typical Alumni money driven institution. Lots of dishonest people have been brought in, and have made their way into management positions. If you are not with them, then they are going to do whatever they can to get rid of you; even if you try and remain neutral.

If you are not a Professor or in the "in crowd" do not expect to receive any kind of professional development training or help in taking classes to improve your knowledge. Most management sees educated employees as a threat and finds ways to keep you from even thinking about attending classes at the university; seminars are only funded for management and management's pets.

pros: Friendly, understanding, diverse, opportunities to learn
cons: I can't think of one

pros: The university is a highly-ranked university nationwide with international recognition. Especially in the past few years, the university's new president and her staff, along with other senior officials, have taken many concrete steps to make this an even better place to work. They just established paid family leave for employees who are pregnant (which honestly should have been done a long time ago, but better late than never!), and made the university campus smoke-free. There are other things that still need to be improved, but at least I can see that progress is being made.
cons: Location is perhaps one thing that many people who did not grow up here will have to spend quite some time to get used to. It is very hot in the summer (especially June), and can be very dry. But you can indeed get used to it.

pros: Competitive research, excellent facilities related to spectroscopy and microscopy. A very good place to work in a field that is a combination of both Physics, Chemistry and Materials Science. One of the world's leading programs in Chemistry, Optics, Planetary Sciences, Geology, Atmospheric Sciences and many more. Just an excellent place to go to school as an undergraduate and a graduate student. Friendly people and a flair of a sophisticated school.
cons: More funds need to be allocated to research, education, financial aid to undergraduate and graduate students. In terms of research, more research facilities will make the UofA a world class university on par with some of the best schools in the world. The administration and management is outright GREEDY. Although we have some of the best faculty in the world, at this rate, the university will lose its faculty and also some of the brightest minds in the country.

review_title: A graduate program doing its best
job_title: Graduate Associate Teacher in Tucson, AZ
pros: In my department, graduate students were generally given teaching assistantships that covered tuition and provided a salary. The health plan was good, and Tucson was cheap enough to stretch $15,000/year quite a long way. Even though things aren't so great in academia for the humanities, the program ensured that I didn't go into debt. And from a purely academic perspective, it was a complete joy: lots of knowledgeable people and a friendly graduate student body that was a real source of support.
cons: The usual problems of a grad program: long hours, lots of work, and little chance of getting a professor job yourself. The faculty do everything they can to help, but most of them got their jobs sometime before 1980, and not all of them stay up-to-date on modern hiring practices, so professional development is necessarily limited (though younger professors are very helpful). The students you teach are generally stupid and don't have the courtesy to realize it. And also the pay is very low, though it was sufficient for my purposes.

pros: Teaching and mentoring young adults is great. When students let me know how my classes have changed their lives, I'm humbled and thankful. Interacting with colleagues and being creative is inspiring.  Developing new technology and pushing the frontiers of my field are why I entered academia.
cons: It's no longer publish or perish.  It's did you bring in enough money to cover all your costs, pay your students and contribute enough to overhead.  As a public university in a state where the funding has dropped so much over the last 15 years that regular building maintenance doesn't happen, the burden gets placed on the faculty.  The most important thing is no longer preparing students for their careers, it now how do I make sure I can bring in enough money to have a functional research group.  This is a problem through out academia these days.

review_title: Worked here as a research tech for several different ecology projects involving plants, insects, and climate change.
pros: This is a very prolific research institute, with many exciting and interesting projects going on at any given time. Especially if you’re taking classes here, there are generally lots of opportunities to talk one-on-one with your professors and see what projects are going on. There are so many wonderful and helpful teachers at this institute. In my experience, my professors were always encouraging of questions and willing to help a student pursue what really lights their fire.
cons: Because this is such a large university, it can be easy to slip through the cracks and miss out on opportunities if you don’t take it upon yourself to create them. Plus there are certain limitations that grant-funded projects place on what sorts of projects can actually be put into action—though this is really a limitation with any grant-based research, and does encourage creative and critical planning to figure out what can be studied that will be both interesting and relevant to the overall grant-supported project, as well as deepen the pool of knowledge that is available on the subject of interest.

pros: Fun and interesting work, culture
cons:
Management and HR.  Although the work was enjoyable and interesting, prepared to be overworked until facing burn out.  HR will be quick to fire you for simple mistakes, and your managers will not listen to you.  Managers tend to have grandiose ideas far beyond their scope, resources, and budget, while also ignoring current problems with their programs and systems. 
For being an academic institution, the UA is very against educating their staff, unless it directly benefits them in some way.  Want to go back to school and pursue advanced degrees? Not gonna happen for less than full price.  The UA is first and foremost and business, the business they happen to be in is education sales.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros:
The College of Optical Sciences is fantastic. The people do good work, the administrative staff is attentive and cares about the students, and the atmosphere is mostly relaxed and cooperative. The college is also extremely well connected within the world of Optics and graduating students have excellent prospects as they leave Op. Sci. 

I have nothing but good things to say about Op. Sci. and am very proud to have graduated from there.

(The ratings I'll give here are for Optical Sciences, not the University as a whole.)
cons:
Optical Sciences falls under the umbrella of the University of Arizona, and while Op. Sci. has relative autonomy, it is still beholden to the university at large, which is where you get wonderful policies like the over $1,000 of BS mandatory fees per year which are not covered by graduate tuition wavers. The contrast is stark between how much Optical Sciences cares about its students (grad and undergrad) and how little the overall University does. Apparently universities are businesses now, not public services, and UofA behaves accordingly.

Parking is also ludicrously expensive and a logistical nightmare; ride a bike.

pros: Nice benefits in general.  The UA is so large, I assume most reviews would be relevant at the department level.  My department looked great at first, but eventually the politics became quite apparent.  The tenured faculty are about the only ones that have the luxury of really enjoying what they do there.
cons: Since all salaries are public, employees often tended to be petty and compare salaries and whine at discrepancies.  State budget is generally unfriendly toward education.  The new Responsibility Centered Management of the budget was being implemented and could lead to significant changes.

review_title: Satisfactory stepping stone in one's career (perspective of a physics PhD)
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Some very good research.
Nice campus. 
Beautiful location. 
Good comunity. 
Many very good advisers to work for (see caveat below).
If graduate studies are funded, pay is reasonable compared to other graduate programs due to low cost of living in Tucson. Career services is active (see caveat below).
cons:
Fees are not fully waived. 
Many very bad advisers to work for, and there is very little protection to prevent graduate students entering "limbo", and never graduating. So you need to be proactive and make sure your adviser has your best interests in mind.
Some sexual descrimination problems in some departments and research groups.
Physics department doesn't provide much career assistance if you don't go academic route. (Other departments have much better industrial contacts, which you can take advantage of if you keep your eye out).
UA career services is somewhat focused on undergraduate/masters (although they do provide some help for PhD's, they aren't their priority).

pros: I loved my time working at the University of Arizona. I was a seasonal cashier at the beginning of the Spring semester. I found that while the lines never ended and the systems were a little complex it was a fun time. I always had new people to talk to and my co-workers were always helpful.
cons: They would schedule me just long enough so they didn't have to give me a break. You work a minimum amount of time and get a 15-minute break. It's hectic so I understand why they did that. That being said for the weeks I worked there I only had one lunch.  I just wished they spaced out our hours more so it could afford us a little reprieve from the hordes of people.

pros: Classes are decent and some professors are accommodating.
cons:
- General RA duties
- Had to make two new boards with info for residents every month
- Each RA had to host at least two programs per month and do a third program with another RA.
- Had a weekly two and 1/2 hour staff meeting, where our supervisors read off a sheet which we already had a copy of.
- Had to check in and have a conversation with every resident twice a semester
- Had to do room checks
- Was an duty for 12 hours once a week and had to do two 48 hour shifts two to three times a semester
- Had to meet with an advisor every week
- E.C.T.

This is all on top of school and it's only supposed to be a part time job, but ended up being more like a full time job and the "pay" was room and board, but this was not enough for all the work RA's had to do.

Campus did not offer what it advertised

review_title: Effective, but truly scope is a point of view
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Tucson, AZ
pros: Deans are generally in place due to handshake mentality in a friendship system that rewards talent: these ppl get good work done.

Yea. I mean woe, the fact of the matter is the utter laziness of student systemic investment in racism to have a researcher say that to our program as we had then no Mexican American students enrolled, was heartening. Real cool guy, too.

review_title: Great place to work, but not perfect
pros:
* Casual work environment -- People tend to be pretty laid back about flexible work schedules, unexpected time off, or taking classes during normal working hours.

* Good benefits -- The health benefits, retirement, and vacation time are pretty good here; not quite as comprehensive as many government jobs, but close.

* Free (nearly) tuition -- can't beat the price, and my boss has always been good about working out a schedule with me.
cons:
* Relatively low pay -- I could make a lot more at a private company than I do here.

* Politics -- the University is a very large bureaucracy, and sometimes it shows, unfortunately

* Sense of entitlement among some faculty members -- if you've worked with many PhD's, you know what I'm talking about here.

review_title: An organization on the rise that is vested within the student community at the University of Arizona.
pros: Upper management actually cares about its' employees, an overall great place to come into work.  They've received a great deal of funding from the community, as well as the school, and they've recently achieved 501c3 status. They hire some of the best talent available to them, and are going to achieve even more success in the future.
cons: A few members of upper management don't belong in those positions, tough to move up. The organization is also still relatively new to the Tucson community, and are still trying to market the concept of what they do. I believe they need to have a more concerted effort to publicize the pantry's efforts and getting even more clients through the doors. They also should be having more food distributions because those have been extremely popular, and are a great selling point.

pros: I loved (and liked) every person I worked with there at the UofA. It was work but it was also enjoyable and fulfilling . Working there was fruitful for both my employer and I.
cons: Never ever confide in Human Resources, they do not have your best interest in mind. Nor should you ever complain about the treatment of others to HR or you may be targeted yourself by HR. If you are having work related problems confront HR but seek the help of a lawyer so they know you are serious. You may also want to put a formal complaint to the Arizona Attorney General's Office. The EEOC may lie somewhere in between those actions but I would not appeal to them without a lawyer. If you see others being mistreated at this establishment Then tell them the above.

review_title: Stable and friendly, with all the issues those cause!
pros: Academia, it is very nice to be able to stay in an environment of academic exploration. The job is stable, even with impending state educational budget cuts. The overall workload is manageable, sometimes I feel undertasked, and wish I had more to do.
cons: The pay is not competitive with the sorts of compensation one would expect in industry. This is, of course, a standard gripe in the educational sector. There are noticeable political and bureaucratic undercurrents in most of our actions and activities. Negotiating between departments is extremely touchy. The job stability can be a bad thing, as it is difficult to get rid of people who don't pull their weight or are otherwise bad at their jobs.

review_title: Everything I've Ever Wanted In A Job
pros: Surrounded by excellent co-workers, no drama, above-average work ethic, positive outlook for career advancement.  Qualified tuition reduction and great benefits.  Management encourages personal/professional growth as a priority.  Oh and tacos, yes, tacos (Anita Street Restaurant is a short trip from our building).  FSO Technology is an oasis with regard to the University of Arizona.
cons: Driving in downtown Tucson is a hot mess (horrible drivers).  Some people that are in our building but not part of our team can be downright rude and typically have horrible manners.  Parking can be a pain in the rear sometimes.

pros: It was a nice job, only worked 4 hours and mostly during the evening shift. I would definitely recommend this job if you want the benefits from working at the school, and highly recommend you get a cashier position.
cons: This job is not perfect. If you get stuck in the warehouse it is bad. It is very unorganized, and people will try to push work on you that they don't want to do. My biggest problem working here were my coworkers. I would get frustrated because people would be on facebook or playing computer games instead of opening up their cash register. There was also a lot of gossip which I did not like. Also, don't expect this job to look good on a resume.

review_title: Great place to work in Tucson
job_title: Assistant Scientific Investigator in Tucson, AZ
pros: As one of the largest employer in Tucson, the school spirit and culture is fabulous.  The University is constantly updating, with new constructions and improvement happening all the time.  The resources and benefits are pretty good, for example, UA Childcare Choice Program will reimburse you up to $4,000 each year for qualified childcare expenses if both parents are employed (at least one employed by UA).
cons: Like most jobs, things can get political.  Sometimes it's easy to get things done, other time, red tape provides major roadblock.

review_title: Worst Job I had and im a Combat Vet
pros:
It had air conditioning and it was indoors.
