Pay was horrible
Couldnt even use benefits, would get complained at all the time
I would be expected to work over 40 hours and not get overtime
I would be insulted and treated like i was worthless
Alot of manipulation and narcissistic boss
I wouldnt even get weekends off and work when the university was officially closed
No matter what i did it was never good for them and they never gave me proper training, expected me to know everything even thought in the interview they said they would train.
Very forgetful bosses they tell you one thing and yell at you for doing it

review_title: Wonderful Place to Have a Long Career
pros: Such a variety of positions, opportunities, and constant change.  Once an employee is in the system it is a bit easier to move around.  So many fields to choose from - both student-facing and behind the scenes.  Have been happy to say I have been an employee for twenty years.
cons: There are more people in Tucson looking for University jobs than there are University jobs.  Any posting of positions can expect many applications and it is possible the employers don't even respond due to the numbers.

pros:
-Great benefits
-Great PTO
-Great atmosphere
-Beautiful campus
-Great support from the community
-Excellent professional development opportunities

I love working on a beautiful campus in the heart of Tucson. I have never had a job with so much vacation time, it is a wonderful benefit. They also have very good parental leave programs, health care benefits, etc.
cons:
-Egos from high-level admins and some faculty
-Some politics
-Raises rare
-Not competitive salaries for low- to mid-level employees
-Many processes 

Working in academia is like working in a different world. This can be a good and bad thing. If you are working in a good department, it is a great place to work. Your team members and bosses may be the most difficult part of your work. People in higher ed are very traditional, slow to change or new ideas. If you are okay with biting your tongue and going with the flow, you will be fine.

review_title: It was a good place to meet a variety of people working toward a common goal
pros: It was one of the few large places to work in the city with decent wages and benefits.  There were also a lot of cultural opportunities within the University that employees were able to attend.
cons: Tucson itself has a lower wage medium than most of the country and the salaries reflected that.  I felt that I was not able to move up in the department I worked in because the head of the department did not recognize my skills and experience to promote me.

pros: Knowledgeable management that makes an effort to teach and listen to its interns -- a good learning experience, though I can't speak to the effectiveness of the technology commercialization process (I don't know whether or not our work actually generates money for the university). I found that my managers were responsive to my suggestions, and fairly flexible in terms of my schedule.
cons: The fact that it is a very large university can sometimes lend an impersonal feel even to the smaller silos. It is difficult to get a proper measure for the impact of your work. It sometimes seems like your contribution is a drop in the ocean.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Benefits are phenomenal; tuition reduction is $25/class at ASU, NAU or UA. Great selection of medical benefits. As for the job-good for recent college grads. if you’re working on degree plenty of time to do schoolwork on the job because Managers stay in office all day. Playing a role in creating a new way of performing medicine is exciting.
cons: Everyone does the same job (recruit participants in study) but extremely different pay ranges. Job is mind numbingly boring as it is monotonous. Very little opportunity for advancement. Since it is state of AZ job, 11.8% of each paycheck is deducted for mandatory retirement. That will be a nice chunk of change in 35 years but living off of 76% of income can be tough as academia pay is very low.

pros: This was the first job I ever had where I felt happy to wake up and go to work each day. The people I worked with were very nice and professional. I cannot say enough nice things about my supervisor and the professor I directly assisted. It was nice to walk around the campus and see all the young students filled with hopes and dreams about the future. It was just a nice environment overall. We were given good benefits too.
cons: Having to pay for our own parking as employees was just ridiculous to me. It was very expensive and very difficult to find parking close to where I worked, especially since it seemed as if they were giving priority to the frat/sorority kids.

review_title: It was a good experience, even though sometimes it is hard to deal with some issues related to students.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: I worked as a grad teaching assistant in chemistry. It was an easy job to do and you are given what you have to teach.
cons: No flexibility to make minimum changes to the lessons based on the students' need or your own needs. You have to follow what they give you. For grading, they inflate the lab grades to have them correlate with lecture, which is UNREAL. Students can be good at the lab or lecture, and be bad in lecture or lab.

review_title: Great place for learning and meet passionate people, weak for professional growth.
pros: Great place to start out, especially in Higher Education, it's great to work around intelligent and passionate people working to make Arizona and education better; fulfilling mission.  Also, especially for professionals with families or if taking classes, leadership is flexible and respectful of your hours.
cons: The College is small and is competing with some of the larger colleges on campus, so they are forced to compromise the mission, at times.  Also, if you're not faculty, doing research, your opportunities for growth (professional and salary) are limited.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: There is quite a lot of lab space here. As a graduate research assistance we don't have many benefits other than university healthcare. The professors are great, and most of them really want the students to succeed (which you'd think should be the norm, but I've seen otherwise at other universities). The weather is also amazing--no polar vortex.
cons: We're still a growing school, but that will only improve in the future. This makes finding a job a little more adventurous when you graduate, but many of our professors are very well connected through the Ivy League-like schools (Yale, MIT, Duke, etc.), so they will help you out with the job search.

review_title: Tucson is a hard place to find a good job. The U of A used to be a good place to work. Not so much now.
job_title: Senior Information Systems Analyst in Tucson, AZ
pros:
- In Tucson
- Usually 40- hour work week
- State retirement and health benefits
- After 5 years employment, 4 weeks of vacation a year
- Some of the smartest people in Tucson as your colleagues.
cons:
- Virtually no raises anymore
- Salaries not keeping up with cost of living changes
- State institution - So even though I did a great job I got no raises. 
- The legislature in Maricopa County is crazy. They have no idea about the value of the U of A for the state's economy.  They really don't value education.

review_title: Mixed Bag at the College of Optical Sciences
pros: It is normal to lend a hand to people outside your research group. Very co-operative rather than cut-throat competitive. Faculty and Staff are generally friendly and helpful. Instruction was awesome.
cons:
Short version: Low pay and long hours due to executive bloat/corruption.

The university itself is not very good at pulling in funds to give to graduate departments. Consequently, our evidently greedy board of regents and president have advocated a mercenary approach to science where we fund our selves via direct contracts with external industries. They promptly take a cut of said contracts, and proceed to spend it on themselves and on new facilities to attract more undergraduate students who will have even less funding available to them than the graduate students.

review_title: I'd Think About it Before Working Here
pros: The benefits are good. Got my undergrad degree with it and am vested in my retirement.
cons:
The only way to get a promotion or raise is by what I call "self-promotions." As a result you have a lot of people who job hop about every two years looking to advance their careers. 

My experience working with the director levels is that there is a lack of understanding on the rules and regulations staff work under. They push to get things done that are unethical or even illegal and it's not limited to one college or one unit. It seems to be everywhere. Even faculty I've spoken with have felt the same.

Director levels that I've work with as well don't seem to have good administrative or financial skills. Who works in a large unit and doesn't feel that budgets are necessary?

review_title: Great job, not so great management style, give us the tools needed to do our jobs correctly such as counterfeit pens.
job_title: PTS Garage Cashier in Dallas, TX
pros:
Easy work hours, easy responsibilities
ability to do homework when no customers
cons:
Equipment always malfunctioning, need to update equipment
negative culture, employees are afraid to say anything to management for fear of their jobs 
if you call in sick you are grilled for symptoms
If one person makes a mistake it is assumed that everyone is making that same mistake and processes are entirely changed.
Promised raises during interview never happen, no ability to receive any kind of increase in pay yet responsibilities are above what a normal cashier would do.

review_title: UA - Love it or Leave it
pros: The UofA is one of the largest Employer in Tucson, and to some extent they are a necessary evil. People are generally kind and supportive. There is plenty of opportunity for advancement for competent people and things change fast. The support for student employees is great and there are excellent mentoring opportunities. The tuition support for staff isn't too bad either.
cons: On the down side, managers have usually been in the U for a while and innovation is slow. The UofA still has a small town mentality and the pace is slow. Quality is subject to broad interpretation and staff isn't always held accountable. Leadership can be mediocre across the university but there are some bright lights. The most disappointing aspects have been the entrenched interests and nepotism - enough said.

pros: A good reaso to work for the University of Arizona is very good job security, once you're in and past probation you have to screw up pretty bad to lose your job. Benefits are very good, and the university of arizona trys to work at helping their employees have a balence between their life and work, they even have a whole department devoted to it.
cons: One downside is that since it is a public agency, you are at the mercy of the state government when it comes to money issues. Salaries and raises for most positions are not negotiotable. And even tho they try hard to help employees with life/work balance, alot of that I feel is just for show, the dept gets very little support to make a real difference in helping people.

review_title: Good people to work with and a fun experience overall.
job_title: CS Section Leader in Irving, TX
pros: Fellow section leaders are generally all friendly and motivated to do their job well. They welcome new members and teach them the ropes quickly, and we have frequent social events. It's a good place to make friends in the department. Professors value the opinions of their SLs.
cons: The department is very disorganized at times and has procedures in place that don't make sense. There is no real reserved office space to meet with each other or students. 391 is a waste of time.

pros: The pace is very lax, so if you're looking for a unstressful job, this would be a good fit. There is no sense of urgency. Generally speaking, it is a pretty hands-off management style. All employees get very reduced tuition, so if you are trying to gain a degree for your self, your spouse, or your dependent, this is a great deal.
cons: There is so much decentralization at the UA, it makes it difficult to move forward on core marketing activities. Compensation is very low, but if you use the tuition benefit, it's worth it. Funding is always risky as the state and federal funds continue to diminish.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Irving, TX
pros: The office setting was very professional, management and leadership was overall very effective. Everyone was easy to get along with. There were several different types of work related functions to boost morale and help employees build stronger bonds. Pay was a little higher than average for most student employment. Balance between school and work was easy as management was easy to communicate with.
cons: I was just a student employee so there honestly was not too many cons. Due to this, there wasn't any benefits or promotions available, not necessarily a con, just an example of why there weren't many cons at all. Just to clarify, I am writing this review for the Human Resources Department at the U of A, not the University as a whole.

pros: Strong community of positive, diverse, and engaged people in the bottom 80% of the University staff.
cons: Senior leadership is increasingly disconnected from reality. Many at higher level are so disengaged from community and student experience that they shouldn't be trusted with making decisions on behalf of them. They pretend to take feedback and hear input but still wind up making poor decisions and ignoring common-sense logic.

job_title: Spanish department Graduate Teaching assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: You have enough time to work on your graduate degree and most of the contents that you have to teach are already prepared
cons: Managers do not care about feedback or quality. They just care about minimum effort. They make the students buy overpriced bad-quality materials just because they have a contract with some editorial. Some of ours students struggle to pay for the tuitions. Since a big percentage of the people who work and study in this department comes form under-privileged families, or are sons of immigrants in the USA, I think they should have at least the minimum of sensibility to understand that maybe, some of our students cannot afford the materials we require (200-300€ pro book).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Research 1 university so lots of collaborators and lots of useful equipment if you know where to look. There are tons of opportunities to do what you want or to create the opportunity for yourself if you approach enough people.
cons: Sometimes corrupt PIs that continue to get their way and the student does not have enough rights ok this front. Remember as a student to keep great logs of all of your work and show it to someone else so there is a witness as well. Depending on which graduate department, there can be political issues and roadblocks. But if you are smart or lucky things will go smoothly-- ultimately don't be afraid to leave.

review_title: Math Dept. with an open culture, could use a real building...
job_title: Mathematics Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: The Mathematics Department has a much more open and less competitive culture than others I've interacted with. The campus is well maintained, and there are some nice places to sit and read outside. There is a good fitness culture here, good gym, great bicycle commuting, and accessible outdoors.
cons: We were supposed get a new building for the department, which we really needed. Only got enough of a new building to house part of the department, very inconvenient split. Compensation is measly even for a graduate program, luckily Tucson is cheap.

review_title: Good and bad. It depends what you try to get out from
pros: Good health insurance. Tuition discounts for immediate family members. (UG level are tax free but graduate and profess levels are taxed and count as an income)
cons: Low pay and no place for advancement. However, tuition discounts offset low pay if you have multiple dependents going to UA. No choice for the retirement except state run retirement programs. (You pay 3% and state will match 3% but you have work for 10yrs to get 100% of match, 50% for 5yrs, no match less than 2yrs) Job contract is given a year period and you have to sign every year.

review_title: Rewarding, but not in a financial way.
pros: University of Arizona has Tuition Reduction and Buying Program perks along with lots of  Community Support and Educational Idealism. Nothing beats believing in what you are doing for work.
cons: Unfortunately, you will work Unlimited hours and although your Pay may increase, your hours will just decrease to compensate for any budget shortfalls.  Additionally the Bureaucracy often reaches for maximum Inefficiency.

review_title: Good opportunities for a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: Many opportunities for collaboration across departments.  A good advisor will encourage you to present at/publish in the appropriate venues.  If you're lucky, you can find a position where your dissertation or thesis work complements the project.
cons:
Limitations on the number of hours that may be worked in the summer are frustrating.  Health insurance coverage has improved, though there is no dental coverage and you cannot add your spouse to the plan.  

Work expectations can vary widely depending on the advisor and project.

pros: Work life balance, 40-50 hr work week, ability to work with and influence the careers of students
cons: Very dissatisfied with senior ldrshp.  Opinions and ideas were not sought out.  Top down decision making.  Very limited resources ($, headcount etc.) after recent budget cuts, to the point where one could not offer min level of service to students in career services.  Significant loss of talent after new ldrshp arrived for reasons sited above.  Lack of real world and business community perspective among univeristy ldrshp.

review_title: Bureaucratic but definitely worth it as a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: There is really no better way to work through graduate school than to be a GAT. The pay is decent but the real benefit is the tuition waver - a full waiver for .50 FTE (20 hours per week equivalent, 2 courses), half for .25 FTE (10 hours per week equivalent, 1 course). You also learn a lot by teaching and managing a group of students. In my department, the curriculum is set by the program, which reduces the GAT's level of stress, but you get freedom in how you want to present it to your students.
cons: The bureaucracy is overwhelming. There is a piece of paper that needs to be filled out for everything except breathing.

review_title: Get a research assistantship as soon as possible!!!!
pros: Set your own schedule, Lab manager is very forgiving about needing time off, Lab manager helps out and is very nice, Freedom to create your own curriculum without professors micromanaging
cons: Research and Teaching Assistant ships are incompatible and will extend your Ph.D by about 3 years so choose your advisor WISELY!! Professors distrustful of TAs, Professors used scare tactics to get TAs to do their jobs, Too focused on how well students write lab reports rather than teaching students  If you have an issue you have to take it outside of the department to resolve,

pros: Relaxed, low stress.  People are satisfied with the status quo, so there is no pressure as long as you are minimally competent.  Good benefits, including Qualified Tuition Remission for employees so you can educate yourself to improve career prospects elsewhere.
cons: See above: the status quo is good enough, so if you are a go getter you might find it hard to get anywhere!  A lot of employees have spent their entire career, including their undergraduate education, here.  This means narrow perspectives in some cases, and some groups of cronies that reinforce rather than challenge each other to improve.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: The UA has an excellent commitment to diversity, and the university has more strict anti-discrimination policies than the city of Tucson, which also has more strict anti-discrimination policies than the state of Arizona.
cons: Needs better health insurance for grad students.  There's no dental or vision insurance, and the prescription coverage only works if you need thousands of dollars worth of medications each year.  Also, it's not practical to cover families or children on the insurance.  It's way too expensive and useless.

pros: Working with Dr. David T. Harris was a great experience. He knows how to treat his employees and get the job done. As an employee of The University of Arizona, I received competitive benefits and also  was allowed to take classes for dirt cheap. It was also solid entry level hands-on experience working in a bio laboratory.
cons: I thought it was a bit on the low end of the pay grade especially working with biohazardous human specimans on the daily. Also, social politics and pettiness seemed to get the best of a few coworkers at times. I guess the negatives of the job were the price to pay working at a university as opposed to competitive industry.

job_title: Grad Student BME in Tucson, AZ
pros: Great support form faculty, but of course it depends on the lab. College of optics is top knotch. BME is up and coming, and the others I dont know about. Low cost living. Nice year-round, but summers you will want to stay indoors.
cons: If staying local, do research that can get you into the company. There are only very few big ones, but they are good and large. It isn't a "big name school" to out of state companies.

review_title: In absence of an effective org structure, fend for yourself!
pros: Flexible schedules and strong benefits.
cons: Complicated and self-defeating organizational structure requires employee ownership and responsibility without the necessary tools or authority to succeed.

review_title: Great education withouth the need for a thermal coat!
pros: It is a diverse energetic university with plenty of resources that include the natural environment. In particular its programs in the sciences (biological, geological, astronomy, optics, medicine) and in the arts with the College of Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture are top.
cons: Do to the economy some departments have left.  I'd like to see them return. The ones that left were a priced film department and journalism.  Tucson had a thriving film industry, so that was hard to believe.  I know journalism has taken a hit due to lack of readers.

review_title: I worked in the bookstore as first a greeter then a cashier. They offer RUSH positions at the start of the semesters.
pros: Since it is a University, they work around your schedule which was very nice especially when you are a full time student but still need to work. It was fun to help other students and visitors find the things that they needed or just wanted! It was a fun atmosphere to work with other students and sometimes run into friends. The management was really nice and again worked with your schedule.
cons: Honestly I really enjoyed working at the bookstore. It was always fun to run into friends and teachers and be able to help them out!

review_title: It has been the educational opportunity of a lifetime - both personally and professionally!
job_title: Coordinator, Administrative Services in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Diversity! Diversity of thought, of composition, of action. There are so many different types of people and backgrounds and viewpoints to be offered and the University of Arizona offers them all!

Size! There are so many different departments and units at the University of Arizona that almost everyone can find the right fit for them.
cons:
Size! Sometimes the breadth and complexity of the University can make it difficult to know who's on first. 

The Arizona State Government! Funding has been an issue for this state funded institution the past three years. It can create an atmosphere of uncertainty and tension at times.

pros: I can develop my own science projects. Good students. Flexible work hours. Concentration of expertise in hydrology and related fields. Great outdoors for field experiments.
cons: Feudal and unclear system of rewards. Huge inequity (salaries do not reflect success). Deals under the table (cronyism). Hiring decisions not transparent (cronyism). Heavy handed and unresponsive administration.

review_title: A welcome addition to downtown Phoenix...
pros: Great place to work, friendly and helpful staff, buildings are clean and new, and the downtown location gives the feeling of a vibrant and exciting campus, although this campus is still growing. Research facilities are well maintained and have a good number of shared resources (e.g. common equipment, cold rooms, cryofreezer space).
cons: Research staff has shrunk due to federal budgets being so tight. Not enough formalized interaction between the medical school and the research community. Seems to be limited interaction between researchers at T-Gen (Translational Genomics, which shares the Phoenix Biomedical Campus) and the College of Medicine, Department of Basic Medical Sciences researchers.

pros: Can be a fun place to work.  They were flexible with scheduling.  Staff was nice and treated me with respect.  If you like working with kids a lot, that could be a pro.
cons: Pay really low, job training was terrible, the work was unorganized, and there were hours of "finding something to do," which drives me nuts at a job.  Also, the equipment in the planetarium is from the '70s, that might have been exciting "state-of-the-art" stuff back then, but it's not attracting new customers.

review_title: Working for the University of Arizona
job_title: Clinical Trials Coordinator/Research Administration in Tucson, AZ
pros: The school benefits are good with the University. The health benefits are just okay.
cons: Maternity leave is only 6 weeks paid, most places are giving parents 12 nowadays. The vision and dental benefits are okay, could be better. Also, most departments are known for being really slow at hiring. Turnover is really high.

pros:
-Learned skills on the job related to correspondence, liaising with different offices, sterile culture, etc
-Some enjoyable people also found themselves working there, making the day much more enjoyable
-Allowed to listen to Spotify 
-
cons:
-Low pay despite requiring a degree
-Lab was mismanaged
-Superiors did not understand the basics of Microsoft suite
-Resistance to new ideas
-Seemingly arbitrary punitive actions against employees
-Was required to come in after-hours with no overtime compensation

review_title: It's a great job, but the pay is not so great.
pros: I have learned a great deal about management and multitasking in this job.  It has especially taught me how to preemptively think of solutions to problems before they even arise.
cons: Working for any school systems involves a great deal of politics.  The inefficiencies throughout the school system make for lazy employees and staff.

job_title: Research Specialist, Senior in Tucson, AZ
pros: beautiful campus; talented co-workers; flexible schedules; opportunities
cons: have worked in 3 departments and my experience was HIGHLY dependent on the PI.  I would never work in any administrative (VP, for example) department again (except perhaps HR).  As a researcher at Family & Community Medicine, couldn't have asked for a better PI; in two other departments I was not so lucky.  As a research tech or specialist you can be taken advantage of with the wrong PI.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: Excellent flexibility as a grad student. Great connections. Lots of support for grads, though almost too many workshops and opportunities. (Are we indirectly paying for those, somehow?)
cons: Some faculty are granted too much power and sway in granting tenure to other faculty. Grad students paid about the same as the national average. Those in the natural sciences (esp. astronomy, planetary science and optics) get paid slightly more. Those in the humanities get paid significantly less. Too much emphasis on athletics here.

review_title: Large research university in a homely, but growing city
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: Interdisciplinary research is encouraged. Freedom to pursue whatever research appeals to you so long as it is meaningful to science and/or society (e.g. publish articles, get grants, engage in research with students). Faculty and staff are very welcoming.
cons: For postdocs, university-wide career development (i.e. seminars, courses, counselors) is either nonexistent or not extensive. Career development is heavily focused on undergraduates and graduates, and deservedly so, but postdocs need help too.

review_title: Would recommend, just not in Student Affairs
pros: I like the fantastic healthcare coverage, educational benefits, amount of professional development offerings, and flexibility in work schedules. You form close working relationships and it begins to feel like family.
cons: There is not much room for growth if you're not based on campus and it's almost impossible to get rid of poorly performing employees. Student Affairs is extremely clique'y. It makes you feel like you're in high school all over again.

review_title: A great place to live, difficult to leave.
pros: Living in Tucson is a wonderful experience.  Small town feel with city opportunities.  The campus is beautiful, and the University really is the center of the Universe here.  Competitive salary for the region.  A very vibrant faculty, staff, and student body provides a lot of opportunity for intellectual growth.
cons: Fewer resources than a lot of universities, especially with recent budget cuts.  Less recognized than a lot of East Coast universities.  Not many local opportunities for networking close to home.

review_title: The University of Arizona is a flexible, relaxed, and a great learning environment with low pressure and good pay.
pros: Low pressure, friendly staff, lots of time for training and other professional development. You are constantly able to attend physical or online training workshops for general things like business communication or Excel as well as more focused information. More importantly, pay is excellent for the number of contributed hours, notably in comparison to public accounting. Very nice and flexible management - whatever you want to pursue outside the office, you can do it!
cons: Depending on your position pay may not be excellent, work is not always challenging

review_title: If your looking for a job this is a great place to work, but not if your looking for a career
pros:
-Good work culture
-Understand family commitments
-Communication from senior management is regular and consistent
-Gives importance to personal growth via tuition reduction, encouragement to enroll in workshops, etc
cons:
-Low pay
-Everything depends on the State budget
-Hierarchal structure of the organization make is difficult to implement anything quickly
-Very resistant to change - Departments will continue to work in a particular way even if it isn't efficient

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: I worked as a postdoc in UoA, People are nice to work with, and a lot of interesting research going on at UoA
cons: Things are not moving fast enough, especially in labs that have been established for a long time. Younger faculties are usually more aggressive in doing researches and publishing papers, but I can't say this is true in every lab. Direct impact is that it really take a lot of student a long time to finish their PhD. Beside, A lot of faculties is leaving, moving to better universities or larger cities.

review_title: Great benefits and work/life balance, poor salary and advancement opportunities
pros: The benefits are one of the best reasons to work for the University of Arizona.  Especially the tuition reduction.  The environment is not too demanding.  Health benefits are great too- lots of coverage and low copays.
cons: Poor salary compared to other places, even those in Tucson.  There is a lot of red tape to wade through.  It can also be very hard for technical workers to advance- there is no place for them to go in the organization.

review_title: Good experiences as an undergrad TA
pros: I served as a section leader for the CS department.  As a section leader, you get a lot of interest from different companies and a lot of experience with the material.  The learning experience is worth it.
cons: You won't make a ton of money.  Your hours are limited to around 15 per week.  It's nice you won't be overworked, but this won't pay your rent.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Full-time in summer, half-time in academic year. Flexible schedule with friendly department. Pursuing a Ph.D. in a STEM field is fully funded. Vey friendly school for the space sciences with cross over a large number of departments.
cons: In a hard science field (with a non-engineering discipline), Ph.D. is a must if you want to stay in the field. A master's degree is not worth much.

review_title: In Tucson with limited professional employment, worth the hassle.
pros: The most valuable benefits are the excellent tuition benefits for employee and family. Generally benefits are decent- health, Arizona retirement system. Campus is beautiful. Many facilities are available- the museums, the library. Helping students learn, conducting research are both noble, satisfying goals. Raising money for athletics. It's all important.
cons: Salaries are low and many departments are poorly managed. Work can be stultifying given the many fiefdoms run by petty tyrants. Salaries generally are low. Women are paid less than men.

review_title: The best university to work for!
pros: There are many opportunities for advancement at the university. There are innumerable departments that make up the university, and many people go from one area to another. It is a great network to have, no matter the department in which you are working. It is convenient to work on campus. The scheduling is flexible and understanding.
cons: The pay is not wonderful for students, and is equal to if not lower a job off campus. Many departments are only open from 8-5 during weekdays, so it is difficult to maintain a full work schedule and a full class schedule.

review_title: Good university to work for with surprisingly good benefits packages for part time employees
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Working on a university provides access to university resources such as seminars, events and gym. The benefits packages for part time employees was really good. Work-life balance was appropriate.
cons: President Hart has conflict of interests with her position at Devry. The university also suffers from administrative bloat much like other universities.

review_title: Lack of good training made the job difficult.
pros: The benefits are very good.  If you find a good fit and good place to work, it's a good place to work.
cons: I have been laid off twice while at the University of Arizona.  One of my jobs didn't give me very good training for over a year and then it was too late when they started giving me training.

review_title: If you want a laid back work environment, UA is for you.
job_title: Senior Applications Systems Analyst in Tucson, AZ
pros: If you want a laid back work environment, UA is for you.  With generous amounts of time off the level of work / life balance always favors life.
cons: One of the most frustrating things about the UA, or any university in general is that it seems like a majority of the employees are satisfied merely doing the amount of work necessary to get by.  It always seems like most people aren't trying very hard, and it's an attitude that rubs off on everyone.

review_title: Satisfying and rewarding job if you stay to yourself
pros: Very professional department, great benefits.  Some room for advancement if the opportunity arises.  Some very good trainers.  Chief is a very down to earth person and talks to you like a person.
cons: Department is currently very top heavy. For a department of its size it is not necessary to have a Chief, Asst Chief, 3 Commanders, 5 Lieutenants, and 9 Sergeants. Consideration on past experiences should be taken in to consideration, and some people try to get ahead in the wrong way.

pros: Enthusiastic people all over the campus. Top-tier research institution. Low stress level and access to Arizona state retirement package. Many coworkers were 10+ year employees who were extremely satisfied with their jobs.
cons: Pay is 10-15% below average. Benefits and retirement opportunities likely play into this, in addition to recent cuts to education funding. Parking passes ($500/yr) eat into salary and are required if you don't take public transportation.

job_title: Student Inbound Counselor in Tucson, AZ
pros: Working in a student job on campus provides flexible hours and steady pay for steady work.  In addition, the majority of faculty on campus are very nice and helpful.
cons: Being a student job, it can be stressful at times to balance work and school.  Some on-campus jobs require students to work at specific times which might not work on some days given the variability in a student's daily schedule.

review_title: TA contract is a pretty good deal
pros: In my department, (College of Engineering), the salary for a 1/2 TA or 1/4 RA + 1/4 TA is definitely sufficient to live in comfort.  Can likely save lots of money if you can live at home for a portion of grad school.
cons: TA assignments vary a lot.  You may spend many more hours with a large class and get paid the same as the TA for a small lab.

review_title: The University of Arizona - An Excellent Place to Work!
pros:
The University of Arizona has provided me with a flexible schedule, reasonable pay, and excellent benefits. In addition, the university environment is a casual and friendly place to work.

I currently work a 4x10 schedule (four 10-hour days with three days off). Others I work with have opted for a 9x9 schedule (9-hour days with a day off every other week). While telecommuting is generally not allowed, these alternatives have provided incentives for employees to stay with the organization.

Additionally, the benefits package for the University includes 11 vacation days to start and increases to 22 days of vacation by the 5th year of service. All employees are also given 10 paid holidays and 12 paid sick days per year. In total, this means that employees can work up to 44 paid days off. I haven't found anywhere else in the area that comes even close to meeting this.

In my current position, I enjoy having the opportunity to expand my experience, take risks, and participate in moving the organization forward. I have been provided the opportunity to attend a number of on-site trainings as well as conferences and off-site trainings around the country. Overall, I believe that the University is committed to providing a healthy working environment to its employees and in providing all campus members the opportunity to learn and grow.

One of the largest benefits of working for a state University is that employees are offered a SIGNIFICANT reduction in tuition if they choose to take classes during their time of employment (roughly 93% off the cost of regular tuition). While not all employees take advantage of this, it has provided me with the ability to pursue a second bachelor's degree as well as a master's degree, saving me thousands in the process!

All of the above has allowed me to excel in my career while not sacrificing time with my life outside of work. I am grateful to the University for the opportunities for personal growth and for the lifestyle that it has afforded me and my family.
cons: The pay offered for some positions within the University is not always competitive in a salary-to-salary comparison with similar corporate positions. However, the benefits and working conditions offered by the University easily offset this.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: I worked at the College of Optical Sciences for a year. Good Professors and good learning environment. Not a lots of work pressure. Pays well as a student. Semester fee is taken care of.
cons: Tucson is too hot in the summer, so you wake up in the morning and don't feel like going to the lab. Sometimes lab mates are not very helpful, particularly the PhD ones.

review_title: A place you will fall in love with and never want to leave
pros: The CCP is an incredible institution that offers a unique connection to photography and the university. Your coworkers will quickly become your friends and soon work wont feel like work, it will just feel  like exercising everyday problem-solving skills as a team.
cons: The CCP is rapidly growing (pro), but of course with that comes some speed-bumps and growing pains along the way.

review_title: I has been great, I started as an entry student worker, moved into full-time and have moved up into management.
job_title: Support Systems Analyst, Senior in Tucson, AZ
pros: Excellent benefits, retirement account and student tuition deferments for myself and all family members
cons: getting to and from work.  It is a big campus, parking is all off campus and my location is in the center

review_title: Good system, but could use a little more organization for MSE lab instructors
pros:
Job expectations were clear.
More experienced instructors freely answered our questions.
The job was pretty fun and very part-time.
cons:
There was almost no training on how to teach.
Some changes were made between the lab manual and actual available materials, but we were not notified.
It technically took more than the 5 hours a week it was meant to in order to teach and grade the class.

pros: Good pay while getting PhD. Medical is covered, tuition is covered. Can spend five years working on a PhD and not owe a dime when you finally graduate.
cons: No dental or vision benefits for graduate research assistants. Pay does not always increase with cost of living. I was basically paid the exact same all five years, which towards the end made making ends meet more and more difficult.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Getting paid to complete a graduate degree is wonderful. 
The weather is generally nice all year round, in the summer just go out at night
cons:
We get paid 20hrs a week for a job that has no end. Getting another job to supplement takes
time away from research.
Experience varies from program to program and even from advisor to advisor.
Academia is an old boys club. There's a mentality of "we've always done it this way" and high resistance to change. 
Lack of diversity of experiences among faculty.

review_title: It depends a lot on what department you are in, but there is drama everywhere.
pros: Beautiful campus, access to restaurants, laid back academic environment, high caliber associates available to meet and socialize as well as work with.
cons: Lots of politics. I have a lot of experience with two departments, but am told others are similar; there is often one person who has too much power and gets paid too much but does not have the skills or sense use their position to everyone's benefit. Your individual relationship with this person will heavily influence your experience.

review_title: Lots of days off, but the salary is lower than industry. A decent place to work though.
job_title: Assistant Research Professor in Tucson, AZ
pros: The location is nice, it's very close to the center of town (even though 'downtown' doesn't really exist). The vacation days are plenty, even when just starting out.
cons: The pay is generally lower than in industry. This is probably more so at the start of ones career. Paying $600/year for parking is pretty insane.

pros: Educational benefits are great. Working on campus is good- rec center, public transportation. Remote work possible.
cons: Pay is not competitive for many units, and this varies even within departments. No accountability for cronyism. Like many academic environments, fantastic employees leave while those who do very little (or harass, or even misuse funds) are able to stay for a lifetime.

review_title: Worthwhile work, great people, but there's budget cuts.
pros: Doing worthwhile work along side some very smart, committed people. Benefits and work-life balance are great, though salary is below private sector averages for similar jobs.
cons: Recent budget cuts have adversely affected many departments' and peoples' ability to serve students. Budget cuts have also limited career progression opportunities and job security.

review_title: Education and Research at The University of Arizona
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Tucson, AZ
pros: The University of Arizona has world class  scientific programs across a wide number of disciplines. Opportunities for highly interactive collaborations abound.
cons: The state governor does not support educational growth, research and development, and academic empowerment in a manner consistent with an executive who is cognizant of the value of education and research to regional growth and sustainability.

review_title: They care about the students, but don't seem to worry about employees as much
pros:
Good health benefits
- Qualified Tuition Reduction
- Chances for conferences and professional development
cons:
- No Cost of Living adjustments: I've been working here for a bit and have only received one raise, which was mandatory in 2013
- No raises: Despite having great performance reviews and asking for a raise, nothing ever happens with it.

review_title: Good place to start, bad to carry-on with.
pros: Learning opportunities within the new mandates of ACA, work evaluation is easy to request, friendly specialists, many networking oppotunities, good entry-level training
cons: The pay rate was pretty despicable, considering what you are doing for the U of A employees. Offer more positive reinforcement - there was a huge focus on what we did WRONG and it can definitely reduce workplace morale.

job_title: Business Analyst, Senior in Tucson, AZ
pros: Work life balance. Its hard sometimes to break through the small town mentality here in Tucson, but things are changing and the U promises to be a great place to REALLY work.
cons: Politics. Infighting and bickering. Too relationship based and not enough focus on true business metrics/performance. UA is too comfortable with the way things have been and folks aren't used to change.

pros: Great place to work if you're not looking for advancement or if you need to fund a wife/child's way through college.
cons: You never get any raises, so your first salary is your only one. You don't even get cost of living increases. There is no movement so you better hope you like your supervisor.

review_title: Quality, meaningful work as a graduate student.
pros: Many opportunities to work as a graduate student.  University research and outreach grants get you out of the classroom and into the community.  Experienced staff that like to mentor.
cons: Not all faculty are accessible due to scheduling and outside obligations.  Office area is very quiet, cubicles obstruct interactions, and faculty are not always in their offices.  Meeting and collaborating takes time and planning, not very fluid.

review_title: A great environment to work in.
job_title: Support Systems Analyst Senior in Tucson, AZ
pros: If you like Higher Education, it's a wonderful place to work.  You meet and work with a variety of diverse faculty, staff, and students.  Tuition assistance.  Opportunities to move around the University but it takes time.  Ability to network with a broad group of employees.  Access to the best Libraries in the State.  A variety of programs offered.
cons: Budget controlled via the State.  Pay raises are not as common as in the past due to budget restraints.

pros: The work environment is a good one. People are open and there are activities outside of work. Only have to work government hours. Tuition breaks. Work isn't difficult.
cons: Work is repetitive and isn't challenging. Feel like a cog in a machine. Not a lot of opportunities for professional growth. There is a fair amount of turnover.

review_title: Not sure I want to continue this relationship...!
pros:
1. Tucson is a lovely, multicultural oasis in the middle of a spectacular desert.
2. Colleagues include people who love this climate and landscape.
3. The UA used to be a great place to work.
cons:
1. As is true elsewhere--and sadly--the UA has turned into a business. And not a very good one.
2. Raises are sporadic and arbitrary.
3. Some administrators who make grave mistakes are kept on, with no apparent repercussions.

review_title: Great atmosphere for collaborative research in life sciences
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros: Boasts a list of highly achieved investigators who are willing to work together across disciplines for the success of their research projects. Great core facilities and other on-campus resources for grad students, postdocs and others.
cons: Tucson is too hot in the summer. PhD programs say that they expect students to finish in five years but the actual average is more like 6.5 years.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Coordinator in Tucson, AZ
pros: Great option to manage academic responsibilities and job duties. Great working environment with amazing coworkers. Flexible times and constant feedback from upper management.
cons: New hires will get credit units instead of an hourly salary. If you need math credits for you major/minor, this could work for you. Need to show up 10 minutes before your shift and sometimes leave 10 minutes after.

pros:
Reasonable salary (pt)
Reasonable hours
Enjoyable students
Relatively high levels of teaching autonomy given that the course was a multi-section “core” course
cons: A lot of teachers in the program are graduate students who openly boast of using their teaching to forcibly change the “problematic opinions” of students who disagree with them on matters of politics, religion, etc. there is a wink-wink-nudge-nudge culture among the management tolerating (and openly promoting, in some instances) this blatant sort of indoctrination happening in the place of a classical liberal arts education.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Some talented professors doing good research.
cons: No emphasis on teaching responsibilities. Whether you are a good or bad TA has no bearing on anything, including whether or not you continue to receive TAships. Often find out whether or not you even will be receiving a TA position (and pay and tuition waiver) a week before the start of that semester.

review_title: Great Environment to Learn, Even for Employees
pros:
I worked for the university while I was also a student, so my department accommodated for my schedule and time commitments.

- Personable teams.
- No unrealistic deadlines or pressure to complete projects.
- Security.
cons:
Sometimes  I felt like I was just building in-house versions of software that already existed. 

- Lack of ambition.
- Poor project management.

pros: Regular hours, good benefits, supportive management. The U of A provides adequate leave (personal and sick leave), a clean and safe working environment, and it is a place you can be proud to work for.
cons: For non-faculty positions, pay can be a little skimpy. My position in particular is at a very low pay level with respect to time demand and responsibilities.

review_title: Depends on what department you work in
pros: Great bosses, great flexibility, great educational benefits, community supported. Good benefits packages, almost-free tuition waivers for spouses, children pay 25% of tuition (service fees are added on top).
cons: Working environments vary drastically depending on what department you work in and if you're a favorite. Advancement opportunities can be limited for staff.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: It's the job you get if you're a graduate student in the sciences. Help your professor with research. Depending on your boss, you can usually make your own schedule.
cons: Pay sucks. While you're technically a University employee, you do not get full benefits like staff and faculty. Also, you're expected to do research and complete your graduate degree at the same time.

review_title: Can be a nice place, but strangely political.
pros: Casual environment, vibrant culture and area of town, good benefits. Only would recommend to a friend because Tucson has very few large employers.
cons: Bizarre political dealings, lack of growth opportunities, and entire professional culture is geared towards soon-to-be retirees working their last job. Should be a great place to work, but it is not. Retains people long-term solely because of the lack of other good opportunities in Tucson otherwise there would be constant turnover.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Tucson, AZ
pros:
- good benefits if you plan to retire from the UA.
- close to downtown
- tuition benefits for yourself or qualified family member
- usually stable
- for academic types, lots of opportunities for lectures, museums, etc
cons:
- periodic state budget cuts lead to layoffs and/or unfilled job vacancies 
- always more to do than people to do it
- administrative bloat -- lots of administrators with competing "initiatives" 
- lack of proper strategy or planning for all the work that needs to be done

review_title: Entry level job to move on to bigger things, good benefits
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Tucson, AZ
pros:
-health insurance and tuition benefits
-vacation 
-professional development
cons: stifle growth and development in individuals, heavy burocracy and not a lot of upper mobility. Management does not hear employees and only care about production. Very top heavy. To many directors and managers and not enough people on the ground. No real onboarding process.Low salaries compared to market rate. Turnover is at least 15% in my department.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: As a TA for a public health class (as a public health graduate student), you really have it made! For every semester employed you get discounts at the bookstore (not for books or electronics sadly), a $3,700 stipend, roughly half off of tuition and fees, and free healthcare.
cons: I worked a .25 FTE and was supposed to work roughly 10 hours a week but in reality it was more like 20 hours a week. Still not bad for all you get offered!

pros:
Health Benefits 
Tuition Reduction
Vacation time
cons:
No promotion potential. Once you are hired you could be left in that position for many years and nobody in management would worry. 
Can have cliques develop and stifle professional development opportunities. 
Human Resources is almost non-existent and there is no protection for employees if you run afoul of your manager.
If grant-funded, there can be changes in funding and can be let go very easily.

review_title: Great environment, but some lazy co-workers.
pros: Lifestyle.  Good people.  Relaxing environment.  Nice campus.  Beautiful scenery.  Good about time off.  Salary is good for the cost of living in Tucson.  Location of campus is central to most of the City and suburbs.  Strong minority support.
cons: Not a prestigious university.  Management has favorites that are allowed to move up when they are not as competent.

pros: Strong research university, world caliber ranking on physical sciences, nationally ranked in health sciences, and high reputation programs in arts and humanities.
cons: Lack of funding and support by the State of Arizona. Infighting and politics that are typical of most academic institutions.

review_title: For better or for worse, it's the best place to work in town
pros: Good benefits, especially if you have or will have college age kids, or want to take classes yourself.
cons: Do you homework with regard to the department - some are definitely better than others.

pros: One of the benefits of this job is the flexibility in your schedule, as a busy student I require flexibility and this job as always met my needs
cons: Sometimes there will be a large event that needs to be set up without a lot of prior notice, so you need to scramble to make sure it is set

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Lots of flexibility, load of work is most of the time less than what it says. Sometimes, there are exceptions: depending on what professor you work for.
cons: In some periods grading /lecturing process may take quite some time. Particularly, in the end of the semester the work load increases substantively

review_title: Nearing Retirement from University of Arizona
job_title: Senior Windows Systems Administrator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: There's no such thing as leaning on your laurels. The standard for competence is a constantly moving target, therefore it's impossible to become complacent.
cons: There's a lack of appreciation in general from the State legislature toward keeping good talent. There's no means in place to reward performance with salary increases. State-funded agencies are always trying to deal with budget cuts.

review_title: Live and Cost at U of Arizona
pros: It is a nice and low cost living city which you can save a lot of money and buy a nice house there.
cons: If you like hiking, it is a nice place to stay especially in winter time. However, the summer is really hot.

pros: Friendly colleagues who value collaboration and innovation.  Pleasant town as well, with an excellent supportive art scene.  Perfect weather for 6 months of the year.
cons: Republican-run state legislature doesn't know what universities do (few have set foot on a campus), and apparently don't understand simple cause-effect concepts, so make large budget cuts every year.  This requires faculty to spend absurd amounts of time chasing after ever-shrinking outside funding.

review_title: Not too bad for hours but crappy pay
job_title: Athletic Training Tech in Tucson, AZ
pros: Flexible scheduling and friendly staff, they work to accommodate a students schedule and changing hourly needs, easy to get holidays off Flexible scheduling and friendly staff, they work to accommodate a students schedule and changing hourly needs, easy to get holidays off
cons: Can have rude managers, and supervisors, no time to eat, long shifts, hot and sweaty in Tucson. Early or late hours, very demanding job.

pros:
Cost of living in Tucson means Federally funded postdoc salaries go much further.
Good health insurance.
Tucson is a good place to live.
cons:
No retirement for postdocs, which is a quibble, but not a big deal. Cost of living makes up for it.

Not many postdocs at UofA (something like 450 across the whole University) means we are often forgotten.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tucson, AZ
pros:
-School spirit
-Pretty campus
-Good pay and benefits
-Good-quality instruments and reagents
cons:
-Very slow in the beginning (took almost 3 months for HR to do the paperwork for my offer letter, 2 months to get my first paycheck, and 1 month to get my computer)
-Stressful environment, very high expectations
-Difficult to get work done with the constant stress and pressure to publish

pros: The University has good facilities, but many require user fees that seem a bit out of line.  In all good collaborative projects and good recognition
cons: The weather in Tucson can be very hot.   The parking is expensive but the shuttle system is pretty good.  People are not very social

pros:
Benefits are great
Tuition reduction can be used to your advantage if you or your family wants to continue school
cons:
Poor management, no clear leader
Pay is not adjusted yearly, not incentivized
No opportunities to move up in career
Criticism is taken personally, can never fix things in job to make them better

pros: The environment was good. Plenty of place.Security was pretty good. Offices are separate from labs. Overall, it is a good place to work as a scientist.
cons: Parking was not for free. co-lab. Infrastructures was not bad. It was new and not all labs are full. Many empty labs. And another building is building next to Bip5 now.

review_title: University of Arizona College of Medicine is a disorganized mess.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Tucson, AZ
pros: Very few. Some great people in small parts of the university.
cons: University has no congruency over last 5+ years. At least 5 different deans during that time within the College of Medicine. No signs of this changing anytime soon. People seem very unhappy and exhausted from working above their pay grade at all times with no ability to move upward.

review_title: If you love tech and people, great! If you hate solving problems, boo...
pros:
As student worker in computer labs, I was afforded much time to work on my own projects/homework
I got to interact with the student body in a helpful, learning environment
Access to a computer with thousands of dollars worth of major software titles
Better pay than food service employees
cons:
Long hours sitting down
Although many students were great, some were less pleasant to receive help
Management could be wonky at times

pros: Great place to work, the department provides all the support needed. It is always nice to work for the University of Arizona
cons: parking is a little bit expensive, also bikes get stolen all the time. Other than that, I never had a problem in UofA

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Earn a degree while doing cutting edge research in projects that matter. Completely flexible hours. Good community of graduate students to share your pain. Tucson is great.
cons: Long hours and extremely low pay. Bare minimum health coverage. High variability in workload and management style from your advisor

pros:
Decent benefits (especially if you have kids that are ready to go to college)
Good work environment
Flexible work hour in my department
Work with some wonderful people
cons:
Low salaries 
Promotion sometimes is not based on experience/education qualification but personal connection
Lots of office politics
Constant talk from management about funding cuts and "tightening belt" leads to low morale

pros: The University of Arizona has a great optical engineering program and there are many benefits to being part of it as a graduate student, including networking with companies, research diversity, and knowledgable and experienced faculty.
cons: A con to working with and being part of the optical program at the University of Arizona is that they often seem to not have enough research positions available for the number of graduate students looking for research opportunities in the program.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Tucson, AZ
pros: Working at the University of Arizona surrounds you with highly talented and helpful individuals who have a passion to advocate for causes and students. The working environment was collegial and flexible with ample opportunity for continuing education and training.
cons: Funding was a constant issue, even in a department that had a larger than average resource pool. Factions and cliques were omnipresent.

pros: Great flexibility for hours, easy to get shifts covered, and easy shift duties.  Lots of time to get homework done while working.  Friendly coworkers and residents to interact with on a daily basis.
cons: The supervisors for this position are very unorganized.  We are consistently being told to do things last minute, or given no explanation for why we are to do certain things.  Many tasks were redundant, inefficient, etc..

pros: If you work at the bookstore you can get your textbooks for free, you just have to return them at the end of each semester
cons: The bookstore expects too much of students even though they claim to put school first. They are first and foremost a business so at the end of the day making money is the most important thing for the bookstore.

job_title: Research Associate/Physics and Astronomy in Tucson, AZ
pros: My time working 2 jobs as a student was excellent. I feel like I grew as an employee at the same time as becoming a better student, and now the skills I've gained are helping me when applying to large tech companies.
cons: There is a very small cap on the amount of money a student can make, so sometimes I would work 40-50 hr weeks and get paid for half of that.

pros: Good textbook loans to students, good on-campus experience, you get to meet lots of people both young and old, looks good on a resume for future job opportunities
cons: The pay is awful, especially for some of the more professional jobs such as marketing, mis or accounting for what we are doing. Just above minimum wage and you get a small cent raise every year

job_title: Industrial Hygiene Project Manager in Tucson, AZ
pros: I had flexible hours and wasn't micromanaged, the pay is decent but public sector-level, the state benefits are good
cons: There is too much bureaucracy and red tape (but I guess what should I expect, it has 15,000 employees), too little support or oversight of my projects

job_title: Health and Beauty Advisor in Tucson, AZ
pros: On campus, so it's convenient and they work well with your schedule.
cons: The management is not very good. Most people quit after a few months. They work around your class schedule, but usually only give you a few minutes between class and work (ex: if your class ends at 2:50, you'll be scheduled to start work at 3).

job_title: Undergraduate Lab Technician in Tucson, AZ
pros: Good work experience, good professors, overall it is was a good experience working for in a University lab. I would recommend it.
cons: Low pay for technical competence required. Some equipment is antiquated and archaic. May be better of working for a private company if pay is more important to you.

job_title: National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow in Tucson, AZ
pros: As a graduate student research associate, the benefits include receiving graduate tuition paid in addition to pursuing interesting research topics.
cons: As a graduate student research associate, the downside is the low pay and the long hours of doing research in addition to class load.

review_title: The University of Arizona is a magical place.
pros: The job I currently have has flexible hours, decent pay, and best of all, a great work environment.
cons: My job has some pretty strange hours, but that's a given due to the nature of my department. Other than that, I enjoy my job.

review_title: IT analyst specialized in Iphone application development

Flexibility in working hours
Chance to showcase leadership skills
More responsibilities given 
Exposure to cutting edge technology
Apply learning from class to work
cons:
Horrible climate in summer to work/commute in.
Exposure to leading companies is missing
Talent is not consistent throughout the company.

review_title: One of the best places to work in Tucson
pros: Decent pay, great possibilities for growth and lots of room for learning.  One of the few stable jobs in Tucson area.  Lots of room for lateral movement.
cons: No raises, unless you plan to move positions/roles.  Parking is expensive, and very little benefits are given to employees.

pros: Best benefits and paid time off.  Great, high energy place to work.  There’s also a pension which is hard to find these days.
cons: Because of the nature of this being a higher learning institution with lots of peer reviews, people who are not doing their jobs well (especially faculty and high level staff) are never called out.  Therefore, managers with bad track records stay for years and years.

review_title: Bad culture at Arizona Public Media
pros:
Some people who do really care about the work they do and the community they serve.
Located in a community full of stories that need telling.
Location on campus is convenient.
Get all the university employee perks.
cons:
Management refuses to take responsibility for low pay across the organization.
Management makes expensive and disruptive top-down decisions without employee input.
Newsroom culture lacks reporting rigor.

pros: Good weather in winter! Low house rents, and low living expense.  The people around here are very friendly. So it's okay
cons: Horrible weather in Summer, it's killing me..... the salary is very low and the city construction is also bad. The public transportation is also bad

pros: The building are really nice and people are pleasant. Less expectations than in other universities like for example, UNC. No complains in that regard.
cons: Tucson is not the best place on this planet. Pay its ok. Benefits could be much better. Summer is hell here.

pros: Great Company! Everyone in a position of authority has earned it or been working there for many years! Fun and easy going!

pros: Good workplace environment. Decent pay especially if you are working on a grant. Flexible timings depending on your school schedule.
cons: Nothing much to say except that the pay could be better... and the tutition reimbursement could also be better so that students that work fulltime can be compensated.

review_title: Great place to study or to work!

The weather, the people, and the level of scholarship!
Cheap rents in Tucson, AZ

The great library
cons:
It is in Arizona
It is in Tucson, Arizona
The pay rates in Arizona are fairly low

pros: Get great experience on the subject and have a chance to work with professions. You have to choose a adviser more wisely. since you need to spend much of the time with him or her.
cons: The working life balance is not that great, if a graduate student have already have a teaching assistant ship position, should them have some less working load on the research subject?

review_title: Great Opportunity for a computer Science student
pros:
* Great Leadership skills development

* Stand in front of 25 students and present

pros:
Tons of employee perks on campus and around town for staff and faculty. 
Flexible schedule and time reporting.

review_title: A good place to hone your job skills while pursuing higher education
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Professional, Structured, and Reasonable Work Expectations and Goals. Flexibility with class schedules. Managers put school first priorities over work as long as communication and understanding is achieved.
cons: Student Workers are often the least paid, and given the least amount of hours  to maintain with regulation. No benefits or compensations.

review_title: Undergraduate Research at the University of Arizona
pros: Partaking in undergraduate research at the University of Arizona was great. At my research group the hours were extremely flexible and the pay was slightly above minimum wage; a fair wage for the work I performed.
cons: It was far from being a high paying job, but that is to be expected, as it is probably the lowest entry position available in academia.

review_title: A different but enjoyable work environment in the food/beverage industry.
pros:
Most workers are personal friends of mine.
Regular customers that interact on a first-name basis.
Stability in job status as long as work was completed.
Work was not over-demanding and manageable.
cons:
Management sometimes did not have an answer or clear course of attack.
Payroll issues occurred if job title changed.
Old cooking equipment that either did not work or needed to be fixed constantly.

job_title: Mobile Web Manager in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Strong community support and public image
Large academic institution with public funding (higher education status helps with discounts)
Professional work environment
Indoors/AC
Central location (easy access/commute)
cons:
Institutional inefficiencies as a result of "government job" security
Large funding swings (years without a raise, followed by mass layoffs or mass hiring)
Rising cost of higher education (e.g. tuition) causes some animosity from students

Congested traffic when school is in session

review_title: Working in Higher Ed is Comfortable
pros: Great benefits, get to work with many intelligent people, get to work with students, many job opportunities available
cons: State funding is not good, hard to get promoted or get a pay raise, still an "ivory tower" bureaucracy in many ways

review_title: Great benefits, work life balance, great mission and culture
pros: This is the best place to work in Tucson. So many opportunities to grow and change jobs. Pension plan, competitive pay, supportive family-friendly culture, work life integration, excellent benefits and employee services....need I say more?
cons: The pay may be less than a private corporation for similar work due to government funding and non-profit status.

pros: fun job, good pay, get to drive a truck around campus really early in the morning, feel responsible for something good.
cons: waking up at 6:00 to start at 6:30 monday - friday, how many papers we have to recycle every day

review_title: It has been a nice experience working with people from a different cultural background
pros: The education has been amazing. I have learnt to interact in a better manner with people, also understand their requirements
cons: I wish more people could get assistantships, especially international students. It has been a pain to pay such huge amounts of money for education

job_title: Senior Design Engineer, Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros: Sort of relaxed job atmosphere, particularly in Research areas those I worked with. Except one three other supervisors and three professors I worked with were friendly and helpful.
cons: Salary was sort of competitive, just below average. Chances for a raise in salary and/or promotion is low. I came to know that few of the departments and very few individuals have a hidden 'racial attitude'

pros: Tucson, AZ has a low cost of living. Overall the campus community is very laid back, with a fun atmosphere and the students seem to be taken care of.
cons:
Looking back on my time at UA I am thankful that I experienced the environment that I did. Now, I know how not to run an admissions office. 

The overall environment is filled with people who think they are apart of some weird clique-y club with a very selective membership. The office leadership has been in place for the past 10 years with the leader being around for the past 20+ years. This office is filled with "lifers" who were born in Tucson, went to school at UA and now work there and who will retire from there as well. You can image what type of leadership style the breeds. 

All unclassified employees (non-civil service), are employed on a yearly contract. Do not expect your contract to be renewed in this department unless you are in with the "in crowd" or you are a typical "yes-man/woman" and do not challenge authority. Many who have somehow managed to last year-to-year, apply for other jobs...and surprise, surprise, they advance professionally and they actually enjoy working at the University. 

I know so many who have relocated or made major changes in their personal lives expecting to at least be employed in the admissions office for 2-3 years. Sadly many only last an average of one year...just one year!! It is evident the leadership does not know how to implement effective, lasting change.

pros: Very friendly, always learning something new. Management cares about you health.
cons: Nothing much, only con is sometimes it can be overwhelming with all the different frameworks needed to learn, but staff is friendly and always able to help.

review_title: Great place to work in Tucson, AZ
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Tucson, AZ

Get a break on tuition.

cons: Administratively, things can move slowly sometimes. I was never in too much of a position where I needed anything from admin, so this didn't bother me much.

pros: I like to work at University of Arizona has been a great place to receive a doctoral degree in Pharmacology and Toxicology.

pros: Lots of cross-disciplinary research with top quality talent. Excellent equipment and professors with diverse relationships with industry throughout the US and Europe.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ

Easy to get in the door with professors for undergraduate research.  Professors understand that you are a student first then an employee, they want to see you learn more than anything.

Great weather and campus

The departmental leadership is very proud to boast that only 50% of Ph.D. students successfully graduate with a Ph.D. (Not sure of the actual percentage but this is what they say and I think it is fairly close to accurate)

pros: Good work environment. A great team. Even though I was there just shy of 6 Months, I learned a lot and gained valuable experience.

pros: Working hours are flexible. Working atmosphere is excellent. There are lots of smart people one gets to work and do research with.
cons: The salaries provided are low. Also, no benefits are given. The medical insurance provided is not adequate for regular needs.

pros: The University offers all the perks of a research institution and there is no downside to having it listed on your resume or CV.
cons: Strategic vision is lacking or poorly articulated. State support is worse than many other states. Few areas of excellence and little energy felt on campus. It's a shame as the university has fallen more than 20 spots in US News and World Report rating in less than 10 years.

pros: People here are almost friendly. Excellent medical insurance. Good work and life balance. Many facilities on campus. Tuition reduction for me and spouse.

review_title: great studying experience, awesome working experience
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ

cons: it was okay in general.... so i got nothing to say

pros: Academic environment where most administrators seem to care about making the place better.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tucson, AZ
